column1: [SAK-179] enable database connection validation code in the sql service
column6:
The BasicSqlService had code to check the JDBC connection before each use, by sending off a cheap SQL query. If it fails in any way, the connection would be marked invalid removed from the pool.

This code was removed because of early CTools performance issues.

The code has been restored. If is controlled with a SqlService component configuration:

<bean id="org.sakaiproject.service.framework.sql.SqlService"
class="org.sakaiproject.component.framework.sql.BasicSqlService"
...
<property name="validateConnection"><value>false</value></property>
</bean>

An override in sakai.properties is also available:

  1. to enable JDBC connection validation before each use (default is false)
  2. sql.validateConnection = true

The default is false, so the code is disabled unless configured in either way to true.

FYI, I've found a way to work around just my immediate resources problem (how to bypass cascading permissions).

1) turn off access permissions to "resources" for the role you want to control
2) create a subfolder in resources for things you DO want that role to access
3) alter the permissions on that folder to the the selected role appropriate permissions
4) right click to copy the link to that folder into the clipboard
5) go to site_info>edit_tools
6) add a "web content " tool with a name that indicates that it contains resources for the special role
7) paste the copied link into the tool url
8) finish/update the site info

Users with the designated role will have approriate access to the special tool, but be barred from the more general site resources.

It would be nice if one could also change the name of the "resources" tool to somehow also indicate that it is for use only by specific roles, thus avoiding undesirable "permission denied" errors, But I imagine a little experience will train users in what they can and cannot access on the site.

column42:
To add some more clarification:
When a user is created, they get the realm from a template based on their type. An account with no type gets !user.template. An account that is typed guest would get !user.template.guest (if !user.template.guest existed).

Sakai currently has !user.template that the default user gets, and that template does not have site.add turned on.

This jira is to change that. Include a !user.template.guest that does not have site.add, and turn on site.add in !user.template. Then, the default will be for a normal user to have the ability to create sites, and if an installation doesn't want a user to have the ability to create sites they would give the user account a type of guest.

I've been doing some analysis on this problem. In rc5 it looks like the user.logout events are being propagated to the database and so far I havent been able to reproduce, we dont have a production instance of rc5.

Their session is remaining in the DB, even though they are long gone, and the HttpSessionChangeListener.unbindValue should have fired long ago. As you can see, the session is attached to a valid server in the sakai_cluster, it has session_end == session_start, but their has been no activity since 2005-01-26 13:48:07, and their is no user.logout event associated with this session id. Hecen it hasnt logged out, or at least if it did, it hasnt appeared in the DB, and the session has not been cleared.

We currently have 15 simular session in the DB, some of them with active locks, and hence they dont look like gosts.

We also keep on getting real gosts in the presence tables.

This could be due to an exception preventing the db being updated on session expiry, but I cant in the code if this exception would be reported. I will check and see if I can find a traceback.

column1: [SAK-139] Support for the vocabularly different schools use, e.g., Semester vs. Term vs. Quarter
column6:
Support for the variety of "academic" vocabularies used by different schools can be handled through a properties file. For instance, at the University of Michigan, uniquname, is generally used as the noun for "username", because it is a term that has strong recogniztion and meaning to the U-M user base. Text in the Sakai interface should draw the locale-specific word for username from a properties file. Defining the text during deployment will probably capture most cases, however, run-time substitution maybe desired for situations where skinning the words is appropriate (e.g., a Sakai installation shared by multiple universities with differing vocabularies.)

Other examples of variations, where word-for-word substitution would be useful could include: Class/Course, Semester/Quarter/Term, Credit/Unit, Login-Logout/Log On-Log Off, etc. There are probably other vocabulary variations that cannot be treated as simple word substitutions, however, it would be nice to at least gather them together in one place or somehow flag them so an institution can edit them while deploying, rather than having to discover them on their own.

column1: [SAK-129] URL to worksite in Email Messages
column6:
When an email messages is sent to a worksite, and forwarded out to the participants, it does not contain a link to the worksite. This can be problematic if the user wants to follow-up by visiting the worksite, and they cannot tell from which worksite the email orginated. All they have to go on is the from address, which they may not recognize.

It would be better to include a link to the worksite in the email. This would also enable to user to get to the worksite in one-step, rather than having to open their navigate their browser to Sakai and then navigate within Sakai to the worksite.

While such email does have a unique "from" address, as users begin to participate in many different worksites, and perhaps some not all too often, then they may not recognize that address. It may also be the case that no email alias was set for the group, so all the user has to go on is a long, unmemorable, unique numerical ID. The content of the email may also be inconclusive in helping the user identify the worksite, as they maybe involved in several related sites or the context may not be uniquely recognizable. It is often the case as well that the name chosen for the email alias is not a direct reflection of the title of the worksite.

A link to the worksite in the email should probably take the user directly to the home page for the worksite. Such a URL would be relatively short and less likely to fall victim to line-wrapping problems. Another possibility would be to link directly to the message as displayed in the Email Archive tool view in the worksite, under the presumption that something in the email caught the user's attention and they wish to see the rest of the thread.

The link could be put in a header or footer on the email. It looks like we currently append everything at the bottom of the email, so perhaps it would should go there. However, since this is mostly a navigational element, then perhaps it should go in a header at the start of the message.

1. If the site is NOT joinable:

a. Make the user inactive in the site
b. Login as user - no longer visible as a site tab, not listed in Joinable sites.

That seems to be the desired behaviour, as the majority of course sites are presumably not joinable.

2. If the site IS joinable:

a. Make the user inactive in the site
b. Login as user - no longer visible as a site, but the site is listed in Joinable sites, and the user CAN rejoin the site, in which case the user's status changes to active.

That seems completely reasonable behaviour, as making the site joinable means its open to anyone.

If the requirement is to be able to blacklist somebody from a site such that he/she can never rejoin even when the site is joinable, then I think that should be a separate feature request.

I'm therefore closing this issue, as the current behaviour is consistent with what one would expect.

There is a very simple solution for this.

See http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-2739 for an explaination.

AccessServlet needs to to be changed to output the filenames quoted, like so:
Content-Disposition: inline; filename="filename with spaces.pdf"

Since we are outputting the filename without quotes, Firefox doesn't handle the spaces correctly. If the quotes are added, it will do the right thing with the filename.

column1: [SAK-73] Cascading permissions
column6:
There are some interaction/consistency problems with the permissions. I have tested these on resources and announcements, they may also apply in other places.

1) When 'Revise' is unchecked, and 'Delete' is checked, the user cannot revise or delete, which makes sense. However, there is no indication of this in the permissions screen, where delete should be grayed out in this case. The user can also still see the delete button in the page when their permissions are set this way, even though the permissions prevent them from actually deleting things. The ideal solution would be to hide the delete button in the interface ANY time the revise button is hidden, in addition to graying out the delete permission check box as described above. This would also solve the following problem.

2) In the case where 'Revise' is turned off but 'Delete' is turned on, there is different behavior in different tools. In Resources, it gives you an error and leaves you at the delete confirmation page. You then have to hit 'Cancel' to return to the regular Resources page. In Announcements, you get no error message, and you are automatically returned to the Announcements page, where the item you tried to delete is still visible. The Announcements page should act like the Resources page.

column42:
Once an assessment is published, it is a copy of the original "core" assessment and cannot be deleted. The rationale is that we don't want any assessments that have been taken to be removed.

That being said, we may want to make it that a published assessment that has not yet be taken is still able to be removed.
column60:
That makes sense, but then don't you want the behavior to be opposite to what it is now?

Once an assessment has been published and someone has taken it, it should stay in the "Published Assessments" list in authoring so that the scores are preserved.

But you don't want a published assessment to be available for students to take forever. If the professor makes a new corrected version and publishes that, then he's now got 2 assessments with the same name floating around for students to take. He should be able to delete the old one, from the student point of view if not the authoring pov.

Does that make sense?
column64:
